abstract.text: Add custom audio processing and MIDI instruments to your app by hosting Audio Unit (AU) plug-ins.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: This sample app shows you how to use AU plug-ins in your iOS and macOS apps. You find and instantiate plug-ins, incorporate their user interfaces into your app’s interface, and work with their presets.
The sample app has targets for iOS and macOS. Both versions have three primary classes.
and its associated Storyboard provide the user interface.
manages the interactions with the effect and instrument plug-ins.
uses
to play back audio samples and MIDI data.
You find Audio Units that are registered with the host system by creating an
defining your search criteria. The sample app searches for component types, either audio effects (
) or MIDI instruments (
). You can also pass values for the other fields of
or pass
as a wildcard matching all values. Get the shared instance of
and call its
method to find the components matching your search criteria.

code: // Make a component description matching any Audio Unit.

inlineContent.text: This method returns an array of

objects matching the component description, or an empty array if it found no matches. You can access a component’s properties to determine its capabilities and find identifying values, such as its name and manufacturer, for display in your user interface.
When the user selects an Audio Unit in the user interface, your app needs to find the component and instantiate it.
iOS supports third-party plug-ins built using the latest Audio Unit standard (AUv3), which is based on the
model. Like all App Extensions in iOS, AUv3 plug-ins run
out-of-process
, which means they run in a dedicated process outside your app, and communication with the extension is done over interprocess communication (IPC).
You instantiate an AU by calling the
method, passing it the component description. This method asynchronously returns the instantiated
or an
if the process failed. You must avoid blocking your application’s main thread when instantiating an Audio Unit.

code: // Use Audio Unit or handle error

inlineContent.text: In macOS, AUv3 plug-ins also default to running out-of-process. Running an Audio Unit this way is safer and more secure, because a misbehaving plug-in can’t corrupt or crash your app. However, the interprocess communication required of this model adds some small but potentially significant overhead. This can be problematic in professional audio environments where multiple Audio Units are used, especially when rendering at small audio I/O buffer sizes. To resolve this problem, AU authors can package their plug-ins to be run
in-process
. In macOS only, you can load an appropriately packaged plug-in in-process by passing that instantiation option to the
method, as shown below.

code: AVAudioUnit.instantiate(with: description, options: options) { avAudioUnit, error in
// Use Audio Unit or handle error

inlineContent.text: iOS and macOS support using existing AUv2 plug-ins. iOS supports only those provided by the operating system, but macOS supports third-party AUv2 plug-ins as well. In both platforms, these plug-ins are
always
run as part of the host app’s process.

content.text: Present an Audio Unit’s Custom View

inlineContent.text: A plug-in can provide a custom user interface to control its parameters. You get the custom view by asking the plug-in for its view controller, which returns an instance of
, or
if it doesn’t provide a custom view. You add the view controller’s view to your user interface using the appropriate approach for your platform.

code: // Call our AVAudioUnit extension to request the ViewController
// We will obtain a generic view if the plugin does not provide a custom view

inlineContent.text: All AU plug-ins can provide a custom user interface, but AUv3 plug-ins may also provide alternative views. A host app can support multiple view configurations. For example, an iOS app may provide compact and expanded views and switch between them depending on the device size or orientation. You define one or more supported view configurations using the
class.

code: /// View configurations supported by the host app
let compact = AUAudioUnitViewConfiguration(width: 400, height: 100, hostHasController: false)
let expanded = AUAudioUnitViewConfiguration(width: 800, height: 500, hostHasController: false)

inlineContent.text: The view configuration object’s
property indicates whether the host app should show its control surface for the view configuration. The host app should respect this setting and update its user interface accordingly.
The host can ask the plug-in which, if any, custom view configurations it supports.
When the host switches between its supported configurations, it can ask the Audio Unit to do the same. The sample app defines two configurations and attempts to toggle between them.

code: /// Toggles the current view mode (compact or expanded)
guard let audioUnit = audioUnit else { return }

inlineContent.text: A plug-in author can optionally provide one or more presets that define specific configurations of the plug-in’s parameter values. You access an
object’s presets through its
property, which returns an array of
instances, or an empty array if it defines none.

code: /// Gets the audio unit's factory presets.
guard let presets = audioUnit?.factoryPresets else { return [] }

inlineContent.text: The sample app uses a simple wrapper type called
to pass to the user interface tier. The view controller uses these objects to build the app’s preset selection interface.
A plug-in may also support
user presets
, which are user-configured parameter settings. You query the Audio Unit’s
property to determine if it supports saving user presets.
If a plug-in supports user presets, you can get the currently saved presets by querying its
property.

code: /// Gets the audio unit's user presets.
guard let presets = audioUnit?.userPresets else { return [] }

inlineContent.text: To be notified of changes to the Audio Unit’s user presets, you add a key-value observer to the
property. By observing changes to this property, you’ll get callbacks as presets are added or deleted.

code: // Add key-value observer to the userPresets property.
// User presets changed. Update the user interface.

inlineContent.text: To create a new user preset, first create an instance of
and give it a user-defined name and a negative
value (user presets require a negative value for this property). Then call the
method, which persists the parameter state so the Audio Unit can recall it later.
If the user decides to delete this or another user preset, you call
to remove it.
To select a factory or user preset, set it as the Audio Unit’s
property. This restores the plug-in’s parameter state to the values stored with the specified preset.

code: /// Get or set the audio unit's current preset.
guard let preset = audioUnit?.currentPreset else { return nil }

abstract.text: Record or play audio, convert formats, parse audio streams, and configure your audio session.
A class that defines a host’s interface to an audio unit.
The audio unit’s last-selected preset.
A collection of presets provided by the audio unit’s developer.
A class that defines an input or output connection point on an audio unit.
A class that defines a container for an audio unit’s input or output busses.
An object that creates a version 3 audio unit.
A class that describes an interface for custom parameter settings provided by the audio unit developer.
A class that wraps a version 2 audio unit as version 3 audio unit.
Identifying information for an audio component.
Returns the component registrations for a given audio unit extension.
Allows the implementor of an audio unit extension to dynamically modify the list of component registrations for the extension.
Deliver custom audio effects, instruments, and other audio behaviors using an Audio Unit v3 app extension.
Connect to out-of-process audio units using the Xcode debugger.

doc://com.apple.audiotoolbox/documentati.title: Debugging Out-of-Process Audio Units on Apple Silicon

abstract.text: An instrument unit can be used as a software musical instrument, such as a sampler or synthesizer. It responds to MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) control signals and can create notes.
An object that manages a graph of audio nodes, controls playback, and configures real-time rendering constraints.
Creates an instance of an audio unit component asynchronously and wraps it in an audio unit class.
An object that provides details about an audio unit.
An object that provides a way to search and query audio components that the system registers.
Gets an array of audio component objects that match the search predicate.
Build an extension by using an Xcode template.
A configuration object that describes how to present the audio unit’s user interface.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the host shows its own control surface in this view configuration.
The base class to extend when creating a custom user interface for an audio unit.
Add custom audio-effect processing to apps like Logic Pro X and GarageBand by creating Audio Unit (AU) plug-ins.
